author: Karen Berkowitz
title: Former Highwood fire chief testifies against ex-deputy in theft trial - Highland Park News
text:
A defense lawyer for former Highwood Deputy Fire Chief Ronald Pieri questioned his client's former boss Tuesday about a 2007 evaluation describing Pieri's performance as "outstanding" and noting that he "far exceeds the requirements for the job."
Attorney Julie Trevarthen was cross-examining former Highwood Fire Chief Thomas Lovejoy, a prosecution witness, on the second day of Pieri's criminal trial on felony charges brought in 2011. He is charged with official misconduct, theft and false entry for allegedly falsifying time records and claiming compensation for hours not worked.
Speaking of the performance evaluation, Lovejoy explained, "I was directed by the city manager that (Pieri) was going to be given a $20,000 pay raise and I should prepare a city memo" to support that.
"He was an excellent firefighter and paramedic and took a great number of tasks under his wing," Lovejoy said.
According to earlier testimony, Pieri received the substantial pay raise in July 2007 when he became an exempt employee ineligible for overtime pay.
Lovejoy said he'd been pressured by high-ranking city officials to give Pieri the title of deputy fire chief.
"A deputy chief's position, in true fashion — totally administrative — was not feasible for the Highwood Fire Department," Lovejoy said Tuesday, referring to the small size of the department.
In the prosecution's opening Monday afternoon, Lake County Assistant State's Attorney Scott Turk described Pieri as a "disgruntled employee" who "wanted to work 9 to 5 like everyone else."

(Karen Berkowitz) Turk said that greed motivated Pieri to falsify time records and claim extra pay for work he could have performed within his 24-hour shift.
Pieri became the highest-ranking member of the department in early 2010, when Highwood eliminated the chief's position.
After Pieri's arrest in 2011, the city of Highwood placed Pieri on paid administrative leave pending an internal investigation into the charges. He continued to draw his salary of about $66,000 until the fall of 2013, when city's Board of Fire and Police Commissioners voted 2-1 to suspend him without pay.
If Pieri is convicted of felony criminal charges related to his employment, he could forfeit his lifetime pension benefits.
